thread.title: Anthony Rizzo called it (sorta) - Chicago Tribune
thread.title_full: Anthony Rizzo called it (sorta) - Chicago Tribune

author: Steve Rosenbloom
title: Anthony Rizzo called it (sorta) - Chicago Tribune
text:
In the offseason, Anthony Rizzo said the Cubs would win the NL Central Division.
Everybody thought he was crazy.
But after wiping out the Cardinals in four games in the National League Division Series on Tuesday, the Cubs just won the division in the postseason.
The difference in Game 4?
A Rizzo homer.
Crazy, indeed.
After the way pottymouth John Lackey acted out every inning, home-plate umpire Mark Carlson should’ve screamed and thrown his arms up after Lackey gave up Javier Baez’s homer.
Lackey wasn’t the only Cardinal screaming at Carlson. Hey guys, go cry on Phil Cuzzi’s shoulder.
In wiping out the Cardinals and starter John Lackey in Game 4, the young Cubs hung the loss on the most experienced active pitcher in the postseason.
It had to be that way. It had to be Lackey against the Cubs of Joe Maddon and Theo Epstein.
In 2002, as a rookie, Lackey won Game 7 of the World Series for an Angels team on which Maddon served as bench coach.
In 2009, Lackey signed with Epstein’s Red Sox, and a couple years after Epstein came to the Cubs, Lackey would would again pitch a Series clincher, winning Game 6 in 2013 against --- this is too perfect --- the Cardinals.
On Tuesday night, Epstein’s and Maddon’s team slammed the F-bombing Lackey into the offseason after losing to him in Game 1.
In the just-completed series, all roads lead to Lackey. Or in the Cubs’ happy case, through Lackey.
Justin Grimm struck out the side after Kris Bryant’s error put Cardinals on first and second with none out. Do they award saves for the fourth inning?
Clayton Richard dominates the seventh inning, but that seems flimsy. I mean, any Cubs pitcher who can retire the vexing Jason Heyward ought to get a statue.
Then again, if all a guy has to do to get a save is throw, then I could live with awarding it to Jorge Soler.
Rizzo hadn’t homered on a 0-2 pitch during the regular season, by the way.
Extra cameras for the TBS broadcast obstructed some views of home plate. Looked like the cameras also obstructed the view of TBS pitch window.
Kyle Schwarber jacked his homer so high and far that it could’ve carried a banner that read “National League Championship Series.’’
The TBS announcing crew called Schwarber’s home run as if it cleared the scoreboard in right and landed on Sheffield.
Or maybe it landed on top of the scoreboard.
Who knows, we didn’t see it land. We didn’t even see it leave Wrigley, if in fact it did the way the TBS announcers guessed.
Maybe if TBS delegated its cameras better, it could follow the flight of a majestic home run and not ruin the view for which people paid good money.
Former Cubs general manager Jim Hendry was in attendance and got to see his draft choice, Javier Baez, play a big part in the biggest win since Hendry’s regime.
Jason Hammel, your plane is boarding.
Next year will still be too soon to see Stephen Piscotty again.
If it’s spinning, Kolten Wong is missing it.
Seriously, Trevor Cahill? Tony Cruz and Brandon Moss?
Eddie Vedder said Pearl Jam no longer will tour in October because of the Cubs. Dude, play Wrigley on the off days.
Usually, Pedro Strop vs. the Cardinals is like Chris Sale vs. the Twins. But not in the eighth inning Monday. And not in the eighth inning Tuesday. Every eighth inning is officially on notice.
Has “Lake Schwarber Drive’’ been taken? I’ll show myself out.
